mn67:1.2: Cātumā is a Sakyan town mentioned only here. | The introduction is similar to [ud3.3]().
mn67:12.6: The PTS reading is preferable: _na kho te Sāriputta puna pi evarūpaṁ cittaṁ uppādetabbanti_.
mn67:16.6: These activities are elsewhere framed as the practice of “situational awareness” ([mn10:8.1]()).
mn67:17.1: The gharial is a large, long-nosed crocodile of the Ganges. The adult male has a distinctive “pot” (_ghara_) at the tip of its snout, from which it takes the name gharial. The Pali _kumbhīla_ and Sanskrit _kumbhīra_ likewise stem from _kumbha_, “pot”. Gharials can be seen breaking water to swallow fish, their gaping maw, prominent teeth, and pot making them an apt symbol for gluttony.
